text: the deponent herein, having first been duly sworn on oath, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION
Hello, Ms. Dixon.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Hello.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you hear okay?
speaker: MR. RAHIAM

text: I'm sorry?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you hear okay?
speaker: MR. RAHAIM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. RAHAIM

text: Ms. Dixon, my name is Stokes Nolte. I'm an attorney in Wilmington, Delaware and I am representing Mr. Chen in the lawsuit that was filed on your behalf here in Delaware. Ma'am, can you state your full name and tell me where you live?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Jacqueline Dixon.  I live at 231 Mount Pleasant Avenue here in Newark, New Jersey.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ma'am, can you tell us your date of birth and your occupation?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: My my date of birth is 9-16-60. I'm a clerk.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then the next question, ma'am, is where are you a clerk?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: At the USPS.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what location?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It's Belleville, New Jersey.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you. Who lives with you at your address?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Myself, my husband and my son.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As you know, we're doing this deposition over the phone which is a little bit unusual.  So I need to ask you just a few questions about where you're currently located and who might be present with you in your location. So are you at home?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, I'm not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where are you?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I'm in the parking lot at my job.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So today is a workday for you?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you are on your cell phone in the car?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there anyone present with you in the car?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ma'am, have you ever been deposed before?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just a brief statement about this deposition.  The court reporter put you under oath and that would be the same oath that would be given to you if you were going to testify in a courtroom and, therefore, you're under the same requirements to tell the truth and to be under the same restrictions and obligations that a judge would put on you if he were to administer the oath. Do you understand that?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And before we started, before I started asking you questions, the court reporter asked you about making sure we try not to talk over each other.  Since you've not had your deposition taken before, there are a couple of other rules that can be very helpful and I just want to talk to you about them for just a minute. The first rule would be, ma'am, please don't guess at any of the questions that I ask you.  If I ask you a question and you don't know, providing the answer that you don't know is a perfectly acceptable response to the question. There may be some times that I might ask you to estimate something in terms of the number of feet between your car and Mr. Chen's car, something along those lines.  And in that instance, I will specifically ask that you estimate, but otherwise please don't guess at a response. Is that agreeable?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It's agreeable.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you. The other rule is that we're really just getting your knowledge. Sometimes it's human nature if you suddenly can't remember a particular date or a particular color or something of that nature that you want to ask someone else who might know the answer, but in this instance we really want to limit your responses to your own knowledge. Is that agreeable?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It's agreeable.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you. The next rule is if I ask a question and you're not sure that you heard the question correctly or you didn't understand the question, please ask me to repeat it and I'm happy to restate it so that when you give an answer we know that you're attempting to answer the question that I ask. When we get the transcript of this deposition back and we read my question and we read your answer, we have no way of knowing whether or not there was any confusion on your part so we have to assume that you were answering the question. So for any reason if you want me to repeat or rephrase the question, I'm happy to do that. Okay?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: All right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Lastly, ma'am, is there any reason that you know of that would prevent you from being able to proceed with this deposition? For example, are you on any medication or under any conditions that would prevent you from going forward today?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Great. Let's start with the date of this accident, August 19, 2017.  You were the driver of your vehicle.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And your daughter Siddiq Moore was the passenger.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where was she seated?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Front seat.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Was there anyone else in the car?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.  Just her.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you were driving a Honda CRV. Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And you were on the Delaware Memorial Bridge coming from New Jersey going into Delaware.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Describe for me the moments immediately before the impact and what you recall of the impact, please.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Okay.  Coming -- can you hear me?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Okay.  Coming across the Delaware Memorial Bridge going south into Delaware, traffic was basically stop and go, stop and go.  As I drive, I notice the car behind me would be like feet behind me.  Then he'd speed up. And how I noticed, I noticed because I was looking out my mirror and I stopped.  So I noticed that he's also looking down at I'm assuming his phone.  So when we got almost off the bridge, he would drive and stop.  As traffic inched up, he would just wait and then gun it, you know, give a lot of gas. So that's how I believe he hit the back of my car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I couldn't hear that last part, Stokes.  She dropped off.
speaker: THE COURT REPORTER

text: I'll ask some more questions.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Ma'am, you indicated that you noticed that the driver behind you, who was Mr. Chen, was was speeding up and slowing down as the traffic went to stop and go. Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And it happened several times until ultimately his car made contact with yours.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  You indicated that you noticed at one point he was looking down and you saw that through your rearview mirror, correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was the time that you looked in your rearview mirror and saw him looking down the time that he made contact with the back of your vehicle?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think your answer was no.  Is that correct, ma'am?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you indicated that your location at the point in time when the Chen vehicle made contact with your vehicle you were almost off the bridge but your memory is that you weren't entirely off the bridge onto land yet.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What happened after his vehicle made contact? Did you just remain where you were or did you pull off out of traffic?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I tried to pull out of traffic. But as I pulled forward to my right, he was pulling to his left because he was trying, now he was trying to go around me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I pulled forward to cut him off because I wanted him to get out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you successful at that?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, sir.  He pulled over.  Someone else called the cops.  I didn't.  And that's when he pulled over, so I pulled over.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you and Mr. Chen talk at all before the police arrived?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what do you recall was said?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: When I got out of my car, he said to me he'll fix it. And said, "Fix it?  You did it." He said, "I'll give you $50." I said, "This is a brand-new car.  You can't possibly give me $50 to fix this car." But he -- this is before I knew the cops were coming.  I asked him did he have his license and insurance, and he stated yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Off the record.
speaker: THE COURT REPORTER

text: (A discussion was held off the record.)
My recollection is -- and you can correct me, Mrs. Dixon, if I'm incorrect -- is that you asked him for his license and insurance and he said to you that he had it.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I asked him does he have a license and insurance and he said yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: He said yes or no?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: He said yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did he provide it to you then or did you wait for the police to arrive?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: He showed it to me, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Before we go any further, I want to go back. You indicated at one point when you were describing Mr. Chen looking down that you assumed he was looking at his phone.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell me what it was about his actions that gave you the assumption that he was looking at his phone?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It was every time the traffic stopped and I looked in my mirror, he was looking down and he would not look up when the whole traffic was moving.  He was moving after.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see at any time while you were looking through your rearview mirror Mr. Chen holding his phone?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  But what you did notice is there was a pattern of Mr. Chen not immediately proceeding with traffic; he would wait into a gap would open up and then he would close the gap?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's go back to where we were. You had asked him whether or not he had his license and insurance and he said yes.  And we established that he had showed you his driver's license.  Did he show you insurance?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: He showed me some papers from the car place that he rented his car from.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you-all have additional conversation after that point?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At any time did your daughter get out of the car?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, she got out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did she participate in the conversation that was going on between you and Mr. Chen?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did she have any independent conversation with Mr. Chen?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Not that I remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Once the police arrived they talked to each one of you independently. Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And my understanding is that you advised the police officer that you were in some pain and as a result an ambulance was required and took you to the Christiana Care emergency room.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was that a yes or a no?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That was a no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'm sorry then.  Tell me what happened.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: When the police came they asked if I wanted to go to the hospital and the two of us said yes, we might as well be checked out. My daughter rode in the ambulance.  I had to drive my vehicle so I followed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I got it.  You followed the ambulance in your car?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Thank you for that clarification. And my understanding from looking at the Christiana Care emergency room records were that you complained to them of neck and right shoulder pain.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, my feet hurt.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you were there for approximately two to three hours while they checked you out and then they discharged you.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I want to say -- I'm not sure on the time so I can't say for sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's fine.  I appreciate that. Thank you. Once you were discharged from the emergency room, did you then drive your car back home?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I was closer to where I was going so I continued on to Maryland. After that I continued on to Maryland.  I was closer to Maryland than I was to New Jersey.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And I didn't even ask you this question, but I should. On the date of the accident when you were traveling on I-95 where were you going?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I was going to my daughter's house in Maryland.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What part of your body hurt the most?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: My elbows and knees.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Could you spell that?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: C-a-t-o-n-s-v-i-l-l-e.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I'm assuming this is a different daughter than the daughter that was in your car?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what's her name just so I don't have to refer to her as the other daughter?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Her name is Raziya.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you spell that for the court reporter, please?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: R-a-z-i-y-a.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did your daughter Siddiq also travel with you in your car from the emergency room to your daughter's house in Maryland?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, she did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long of a drive is it from Christiana Hospital to your daughter's house?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I'm not sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is the town where she lives north of Baltimore or south of Baltimore?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I use my GPS.  I'm not sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you able to drive the entire way from Christiana Care to your daughter's house?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I had to.  I was shooken up, but yes, I had to.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how long did stay at your daughter's house before returning home?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Two days.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Two days?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Two days.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there a particular purpose or just a general visit?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: There was a purpose.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was the purpose?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It was my grandson's birthday.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And were you able to participate in the birthday festivities?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What were the birthday festivities that you were not able to participate in?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Well, you know, his cake.  By the time I got there it was too late. There nothing that I could do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why don't you tell me when you left the emergency room before you got to your daughter's house in Maryland, how were you feeling?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I was feeling a bit shooken up.  I was never in a car accident at all, any kind of accident.  So I was a bit like nervous about it, so going to my daughter's house it took me longer to get there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you in pain after you left the emergency room?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes.  The emergency room didn't do anything for me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where were you having pain when you left the emergency room?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It was like behind my head, in the neck, that part.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: And the shoulder was just stiff, but behind the neck was the pain itself.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did they give you anything at the emergency room for the pain?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  When you got to your daughter's house, did you take anything for pain?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes.  She gave me something.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember what it was?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it a prescription or was it over-the-counter?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Like over-the-counter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Like a Tylenol or --
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Advil or something like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Advil or something like that. Okay.  Great. Eventually it appears that you went to see a chiropractic physician by the name of Dr. Chesney at Affiliated Sports Clinic.  And from the medical records it looks like the date, first date you saw him was September 18th, 2017. Is that consistent with your memory?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I'm not that sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember seeing Dr. Chesney and you're just not sure what date it was?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I'm not sure of the date.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know how you got to see Dr. Chesney, how you found that particular chiropractor?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you tell me how?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I went to another lawyer and he sent me to Chesney.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that Mr. Kessler?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes, Kessler.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you ever seen Attorney Kessler prior to the time you went to visit him after this accident?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.  I never knew him.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell me when you went to see Dr. Chesney what kind of pain and problems you were having?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: When I went to see Chesney, it was hard for me to hold my head down and if I laid down and I tried to prop my head up, that's when I felt pain.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Prior to seeing Dr. Chesney, did you have a personal physician?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Oh, I always did, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was that Dr. Silva?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, it wasn't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Dr. Silva was a doctor that you were seeing for hypotension?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.  Dr. Silva is the doctor that I have now.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, okay.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I had another doctor, but he dropped my insurance.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Gotcha.  Was that doctor -- and I might not pronounce his name correctly -- Picciano?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Picciano.  Dr. Picciano.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: He dropped your insurance so you had to switch to Dr. Silva?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: So I had to switch, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you remember that switch occurred sometime after the August 2017 accident?  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, ma'am, we have some records for a bunch of doctors and I'm not going to go through all of those records individually, but I'm going to read off the names of the doctors that I'm aware of and then I'm going to ask if I missed any. Bear with me and we're going to try to go through this. I have records from a doctor by the name of Ghanekar.  Do you remember Dr. Ghanekar?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Did he give a first name?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, there might be one in the records, but I don't have that in front of me.  Let me look and see what I can find. Hold on. How about Ramesh Ghanekar?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I'm not sure on that doctor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So if you're not sure, you wouldn't remember the date that you first started treating with him.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you remember a Dr. Patel?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes. Oh, I know Ramesh.  Now I remember.  I still don't know his name. That was from the chiropractor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So I want to make sure I understand. The chiropractor sent you to see Dr. Patel?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It was there, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry.  Dr. Patel was at the chiropractor's office?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I guess they're all affiliated.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So when you went to see Dr. Patel, you saw him at the same place, that same office building that you went to see Dr. Chesney?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Patel is in I want to say Clifton. I'm not sure exactly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: He had an outside office.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You think it might have been in Clifton, New Jersey?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you remember what you saw Dr. Patel for?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Dr. Patel gave me some shots in the back of my neck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you remember how many injections he gave you?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I had two.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Were they helpful at all?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: To some point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: They helped a little bit but didn't relieve your pain entirely?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  You also saw a Dr. Datta, D-a-t-t-a.  Do you remember that doctor?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: (Pause).
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry.  Did you answer that question?  I didn't hear it.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I said no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, okay.  Do you remember getting injections from more than one doctor?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, I didn't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you repeat that?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I don't remember.  No.  The injections were only from Patel.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, you also had some testing done.  Do you remember having an EMG test?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's electric shock, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you had that both in your arms and in your legs, correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you had some MRI's done.  Do you remember that?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you had MRI's done to your neck and to your low back?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the doctor that did the MRI's was a doctor named Dr. Pomerantz.  Do you recall that?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I don't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember ever talking to the doctor that did the MRI's?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: They just did the MRI's and said that the MRI report would go to the chiropractor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you seen a copy of those reports at any point?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I think they gave them to me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And then we have some records that appear to be prior to the August automobile accident from two doctors that you saw back in 2016 and 2017 for problems you were having in your right shoulder. You went to see a Dr. Sutain, Sutain, and a Dr. Ropiak, who performed a rotator cuff surgery on you in October of 2016 and March of 2017. Do you recall that?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So you had to have rotator cuff surgery in October and then you had to have it redone in March because of a frozen shoulder condition?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  After March of 2017, that second surgery that Dr. Ropiak did, do you recall how your shoulder felt?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It was movable.  It was still no better.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So it was better but not 100 percent?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, not 100 percent better.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I want to go back to your personal physician, Dr. Picciano. His records have an indication in July of 2016, so this is prior to the first right shoulder surgery, that you had a fall and you injured your right shoulder. Do you remember that?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.  I don't remember telling him that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember how your right shoulder came to be injured that required surgery?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No, I don't remember because I throw mail, I'm tossing packages.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your job required a lot of use of your arms?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, in this case we have a second automobile accident that you were involved in that occurred on October 24th of 2017. You recall that, correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That was approximately a little more than two months after the August accident.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: It was in October.  I don't remember dates.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  You were driving your car and you were hit broadside by another vehicle that ran a stop sign.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: He T-boned me, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And your daughter Siddiq Moore was in the car with you?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Siddiq was in the car.

speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.

text: Which car?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The Honda CRV.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Same car.

text: Okay.  And I want to ask you questions a little bit about the doctors that your daughter and you went to see. They were the very same doctors, correct? You both went to see Dr. Chesney, you both went to see Dr. Patel, you both went to see Dr. Datta, you both went to see Dr. Ghanekar.

text: Okay.

text: Sometimes.  No, I can't say correct.

text: I know it wasn't all the time.

text: Okay.  But, for example, the date that you had your EMG, which was November 10th of 2017, is the same date she had her EMG.  Is that correct?

text: Correct.

text: Okay.  And I want to go back now and just kind of talk briefly about the types of treatment that -- well, strike that.  I apologize. In addition to the doctors that I have indicated, are there any other doctors that you went to and got treatment for related to this accident that you recall?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: No.

text: Okay.  Then I'll ask the question I started to ask. In looking at the types of medical treatment that you got for this accident, you went to see Dr. Chesney, a chiropractor, and you had chiropractic treatment.  Is that correct?

text: That's correct.

speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.

speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: That's correct.

text: Okay.  Do you recall any other types of medical care that you received following the August 2017 accident?

text: No.

text: Okay.  Tell me, if you can, after the October 24, 2017 accident -- this is the second accident -- did you feel that you had pain -- strike that.  Let me ask it a different way.  I apologize. So after the August 2017 accident you were going to see to see Dr. Chesney and you had chiropractic care. Prior to the October 24, 2017 accident, the second accident, did you feel that you had recovered at all from the problems that the August accident gave you?

text: No.

text: The second accident, the October accident.

text: The second accident didn't change anything.

text: Okay.  So you felt about the same in terms of your pain complaints the day before the October accident as you did after the October accident?

text: Correct.

text: I'm sorry.  I didn't hear that.
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.

text: Correct.

speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Correct.

text: They changed it.

text: Correct.

text: No.

text: Unsure.

text: I believe so, yes.

speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I'm not sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Can you repeat that?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'll reask it again, yes. Can you tell me do you have complaints from your physical reaction of your body, is your body giving you problems that you believe were caused by the first accident in August of 2017?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: I want to say that off and on I still have pain in my neck.  Do I deal with it?  Yes.  Do I take anything?  Yes.

text: Are you able to tell me how often you notice the neck pain?
speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Like it comes and goes.  Like I may feel it now and then I won't feel it for like a week or two.  It all depends on which way I turn my head.

speaker: MR. NOLTE

text: Yes.

There's a paragraph called Present Complaints and the doctor wrote, quote, "The claimant presents pain-free. She states she is fully recovered and is at pre-MVA status.  The claimant was having neck, upper back and lower back pain as a result of the MVA in August 2017 prior to the MVA in October of 2017.  She was still symptomatic with cervical-thoracic and lower back pain at the time of the October 24, 2017 accident.  Aside from occasional stiffness in her knees, the claimant denies any lower extremity involvement or complaints. "Again" -- I'm fast forwarding -- "again all complaints are fully resolved." Do you remember talking to Dr. Feder and telling him that you were pain-free?

text: No.

text: Okay.

I'm back.  I've looked through my notes.  I do have one other area that I want to ask you some questions about.
